elements.content: Two new symmetric and unsymmetrical semirigid organic ligands 2,5-bis(4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)phenyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L1) and 4-(1H-1,2,4-trizol-1-ylmethyl)benzoic acid (L2) have been prepared. L2 was generated from L1 by a hydrothermal reaction via the hydrolysis of the central oxadiazole ring of L1. The solution and hydrothermal reactions of L1 with various inorganic M(II) (M = Cd, Co, Zn, and Cu) ions have been investigated. Compounds [Cd(L1)2](NO3)2 (1), [Cu(L1)2](NO3)2 (2), and [Cu(L1)]Cl2·2(H2O) (3) were obtained in solution by a combination of L1 with corresponding metal salts, while compounds Zn(L2)2 (4), Co(L2)2 (5), and [Co(L2)2]·H2O (6) were synthesized by a hydrothermal technique with in situ generated unsymmetrical L2 ligand. In addition, compounds 4−6 could also be prepared by direct combination of L2 with corresponding metal salts under the same hydrothermal conditions. All six new coordination polymers were fully characterized by infrared spectroscopy, elemental analysis, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and thermogravimetric analysis. Compounds 1−3 are isostructural and feature a one-dimensional chain motif composed of an M2L2-macroring as the based building block. Compounds 4 and 5 form a novel chiral and acentric non-interpenetrating two-dimensional network consisting of right- and left-handed helical ML chains, respectively. Compound 6 adopts a unique non-interpenetrating three-dimensional framework, in which the inorganic ···Co−O−Co−O··· chains are connected to each other through unsymmetric L2 ligands. In the solid state, L1−L2 and their complexes 1−6 are luminescent. The Kurtz powder measurements show that both 4 and 5 are nonlinear optical (NLO) active and have potential applications as NLO-active materials.

elements.content: Self-assembly of organic ligands and inorganic metal ions is one of the most efficient and widely utilized approaches toward the construction of metal−organic coordination polymers or supramolecular complexes. During the past few decades, numerous such materials have been synthesized, providing a variety of infinite or discrete frameworks of one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1D, 2D, or 3D) motifs composed of single and/or polynuclear metal nodes and organic linkages. In particular, thermally stable and robust coordination polymers have attracted much attention due to their potential application for molecular storage, magnetic, electronic, nonlinear optical (NLO) and catalytic properties. To date, solution and hydrothermal reactions are the most important synthetic techniques to access to such materials. Compared to solution reactions, a hydrothermal technique seems play more important role to generate thermally stable and robust coordination frameworks. Very recently, a new strategy developed by chemists is to construct coordination polymers based on metal ions and in situ generation of organic ligands under hydrothermal conditions. For example, organic carboxylate ligands containing metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) can be obtained by a combination of metal ions or coordinatively unsaturated complexes with organic precursors that possess cyano, ester, carbon−carbon double bond, or ketone functionalities.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Self-assembly of organic ligands and inorganic metal ions is one of the most efficient and widely utilized approaches toward the construction of metal-organic coordination polymers or supramolecular complexes. During the past few decades, numerous such materials have been synthesized, providing a variety of infinite or discrete frameworks of one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1D, 2D, or 3D) motifs composed of single and/or polynuclear metal nodes and organic linkages. In particular, thermally stable and robust coordination polymers have attracted much attention due to their potential application for molecular storage, magnetic, electronic, nonlinear optical (NLO) and catalytic properties. To date, solution and hydrothermal reactions are the most important synthetic techniques to access to such materials. Compared to solution reactions, a hydrothermal technique seems play more important role to generate thermally stable and robust coordination frameworks. Very recently, a new strategy developed by chemists is to construct coordination polymers based on metal ions and in situ generation of organic ligands under hydrothermal conditions. For example, organic carboxylate ligands containing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can be obtained by a combination of metal ions or coordinatively unsaturated complexes with organic precursors that possess cyano, ester, carbon-carbon double bond, or ketone functionalities.

elements.content: We have recently designed and synthesized a series of coordination polymers and discrete supramolecular complexes based on five-membered oxadiazole or triazole bridging bent organic ligands with pyridyl, cyano, aminophenyl, acetylenylphenyl, or cyanophenylacetylenyl groups as the terminal coordination sites. As expected, the adoption of such bent oxadiazole or triazole bridging ligands led to a broader palette of coordination polymers and supramolecular complexes that cannot be achieved with common linear ligands. It is known that an oxadiazole group could be transformed to a carboxylate group under hydrothermal conditions. Thus, the oxadiazole moiety is a potential carboxylate group, which endows such types of organic ligands more diverse functional information, consequently resulting in more unprecedented structures with novel topological features.

As expected, the adoption of such bent oxadiazole or triazole bridging ligands led to a broader palette of coordination polymers and supramolecular complexes that cannot be achieved with common linear ligands. It is known that an oxadiazole group could be transformed to a carboxylate group under hydrothermal conditions. Thus, the oxadiazole moiety is a potential carboxylate group, which endows such types of organic ligands more diverse functional information, consequently resulting in more unprecedented structures with novel topological features.

elements.content: In our continuing efforts to systematically investigate the self-assembly on the basis of bent ligands of this type, we designed and synthesized the symmetric semirigid oxadiazole bridging ligand L1 and unsymmetric ligand L2 generated from L1 under hydrothermal conditions. We report herein the construction of six new metal−organic coordination polymers, namely, [Cd(L1)2](NO3)2 (1), [Cu(L1)2](NO3)2 (2), [Cu(L1)]Cl2·2(H2O) (3), Zn(L2)2 (4), Co(L2)2 (5), and [Co(L2)2]·H2O (6) based on them, as shown in Scheme 1.

Materials and Methods. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 400−4000 cm-1 range using a Perkin-Elmer 1600 FTIR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer model 2400 analyzer. 1H NMR data were collected using an AM-300 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in δ relative to TMS. All fluorescence measurements were carried out on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorimeter (Varian, Australia) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out using a TA Instrument SDT 2960 simultaneous DTA-TGA under flowing nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å).

Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 400-4000 cm-1 range using a Perkin-Elmer 1600 FTIR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer model 2400 analyzer. 1H NMR data were collected using an AM-300 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in δ relative to TMS. All fluorescence measurements were carried out  on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorimeter (Varian, Australia) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out using a TA Instrument SDT 2960 simultaneous DTA-TGA under flowing nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å).

elements.content: Preparation of L1. K2CO3 (0.69 g, 10 mmol) was added with stirring to a solution of bis(4-bromomethylphenyl)oxadiazole (2.04 g, 5 mmol) and 1,2,4-triazole (0.69 g, 10 mmol) in anhydrous CH3CN (50 mL) at ambient temperature under nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was stirred for 12 h at ambient temperature [monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC)]. After removal of solvent under vacuum, the residue was purified on silica gel by column using CH3COCH3 as the eluent to afford L1 as the white crystalline solids (0.79 g, 2.06 mmol). Yield, 41%. mp = 222−224 °C. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3094(s), 2953(w), 1618(w), 1555(m), 1505(s), 1268(s), 1149(s), 1014(s), 821(m), 723(s). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  8.14(s, −NCH−N, 2H), 8.01(s, −CHN−N, 2H), 8.16−7.41(AA‘BB‘, 8H, p-C6H4), 5.45(s, 4H, −CH2−). Anal. Calcd. for C20H16N8O2:  C 62.49, H 4.20, N 29.15; Found:  C 62.89, H 4.30, N 28.75.

elements.content: Preparation of L2. L1 (40.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) and water (5 mL) were placed in an acid digestion bomb. The mixture was heated at 190 °C for 40 h, cooled to 154 °C at a rate of 6 °C h-1, and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The mixture was held at room temperature for an additional 6 h. Colorless block crystals were isolated from the bomb in 77% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3118(vs), 2950(w), 1693(vs), 1611 m), 1516(s), 1432(m), 1275(s), 1142(s), 1013(m), 870(m), 731(s). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  12.99 (s, 1H, −OH), 8.68 (s, 1H, =C−NCH−N−), 8.00−8.03 (d, 1H, −N−CHN−N−), 7.92−7.32 (AA‘BB‘, 4H, p-C6H4), 5.50 (s, 2H, −CH2−). Anal. Calcd. for C10H9N3O2:  C 59.11, H 4.46, N 20.68; Found:  C 59.89, H 4.10, N 21.26.

elements.content: Preparation of [Cd(L1) 2 ](NO 3 ) 2 (1). A solution of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (10.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) in methanol (8 mL) was layered onto a solution of L1 (15.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL). The solutions were left for about 3 days at room temperature, and colorless crystals (17.12 mg, 0.034 mmol) were obtained. Yield, 87% (based on L1). IR (KBr, cm-1):  3130(s), 1618(m), 1555(s), 1403(vs), 1322(s), 1128(s), 983(m), 852(s), 726(s). 1HNMR (300 MHz, DMSO, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  8.40 (s, 2H, −C6H4), 8.27−8.25 (d, 2H, −C6H4), 7.95−7.81 (m, 10H, −C6H4), 7.76−7.71 (t, 2H, −C6H4), 7.37 (s, C6H6). Anal. Calcd. for C20H16Cd0.50N9O4 :  C 47.79, H 3.21, N 25.08; Found:  C 47.46, H 3.51, N 24.84.

elements.content: Preparation of [Cu(L1) 2 ](NO 3 ) 2 (2). A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (2.65 mg, 0.011 mmol) in water (2 mL) was layered onto a solution of L1 (2.5 mg, 0.005 mmol) in CH3CN (2 mL). The solutions were left for 4 days at room temperature, and blue crystals were obtained (2.7 mg, 0.028 mmol). Yield, 84% (based on L1). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3123(s), 1525(m), 1501(m), 1384 (vs), 1127(m), 820 (m), 727(m), 644(m). Anal. Calcd. for C40H32CuN18O8:  C 49.91, H 3.37, N 17.46; Found:  C 49.56, H 3.51, N 17.64. In additional, compound 2 could also be obtained in a water (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O)/methanol (L1) mixed solvent system, which was confirmed by the X-ray single-crystal analysis.

elements.content: Preparation of Co(L2) 2 (4). L1 (40.3 mg, 0.10 mmol), Co(OAc)2·2H2O (94.6 mg, 0.2mmol) and water (5 mL) were placed in an acid digestion bomb (20 mL). The mixture was heated at 190 °C for 40 h, cooled to 154 °C at a rate of 6 °C h-1, and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The mixture was held at room temperature for an additional 6 h. Red-purple block crystals (82 mg, 0.18 mmol) were isolated from the bomb in 84% yield (based on L2). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3114(s), 2991(w), 1623(s), 1568(m), 1365(s), 789(m), 738(m). Anal. Calcd. for C20H16CoN6O4:  C 51.85, H 3.48, N 18.14; Found:  C 51.40, H 3.55, N 18.91. In addition, compound 4 could also be generated directly by combination of L2 and CoCl2·6H2O under the same hydrothermal conditions in lower yield.

elements.content: Single-Crystal Structure Determination. Suitable single crystals of L2 and 1−6 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. X-ray intensity data were measured at 293 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). The raw frame data for L2 and 1−6 were integrated into SHELX-format reflection files and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects using SAINT. Corrections for incident and diffracted beam absorption effects were applied using SADABS. None of the crystals showed evidence of crystal decay during data collection. All structures were solved by a combination of direct methods and difference Fourier syntheses and refined against F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique. Crystal data, data collection parameters, and refinement statistics for L2 and 1−6 are listed in Tables and 2. Relevant interatomic bond distances and bond angles for 1−6 are given in Tables −8.

Ligand Synthesis and Structural Analysis. So far, rigid and flexible organic bidentate and multidentate ligands have been the main theme in the chemistry of coordination polymers. All these bidentate and multidentate N-donor containing ligands have proven to be among the most important types of organic ligands for the design and construction of coordination polymers exhibiting remarkable polymeric structural motifs. However, up to now, very little attention has been paid to the coordination polymers or supramolecular complexes generated from semirigid organic ligands. Semirigid ligands fill a void between rigid and flexible organic ligands and offer the possibility for construction of frameworks with novel patterns not easily achievable by rigid and flexible ligands. We are interested in how different types of semirigid linking groups as well as different terminal coordinating sites impact the coordination and supramolecular motifs of a variety of metal complexes based on five-membered heteroatom-ring bridging ligands. Following this approach, we have expanded oxadiazole-bridged rigid and flexible ligands to the semirigid ligand L1. The semirigid large-length-scale ligand L1 was synthesized by the reaction of bis(4-bromomethylphenyl)oxadiazole (S) and 1,2,4-triazole in the presence of K2CO3 in CH3CN at ambient temperature in moderate yield. The previous study indicated that the oxadiazole ring is prone to hydrolyze into a carbohydrazide moiety under basic conditions. The results herein demonstrate that the oxadiazole ring is stable under our experimental conditions (K2CO3, r.t.). In addition, L1 is soluble in common polar organic solvents such as CH2Cl2, CHCl3, THF, DMSO, and DMF, which potentially facilitates the solution reactions between L1 and inorganic metal salts. When L1 was treated under hydrothermal conditions (H2O, 190 °C and sealed bomb), L2 was generated as the hydrolysis product in high yield. No carbohydrazide bridging spacer L3 was isolated during the reactions. To further confirm the structure of L2, we analyzed it using single-crystal X-ray diffraction. L2 crystallizes in a chiral space group P2(1). As shown in Figure , phenylcarboxylate and triazole groups are bridged by a methylene group, which gives rise to ligand L2 being unsymmetric with an angular backbone driven by the sp3 configuration of the bridging carbon atom. The dihedral angle between the phenyl ring and the 1,2,4,-triazole ring is 111°. The terminal carboxylate moiety has a 4.5° dihedral angle with the plane of the attached phenyl ring. Such a chiral asymmetric bent organic spacer with divergent properties is potentially useful in the construction of polymeric homochiral helices and especially acentric MOFs with NLO properties. Compared to L1, L2 has relatively poor solubility in common organic solvents at room temperature. Thus, solution reactions based on it are limited.

Results and Discussion

All these bidentate and multidentate N-donor containing ligands have proven to be among the most important types of organic ligands for the design and construction of coordination polymers exhibiting remarkable polymeric structural motifs. However, up to now, very little attention has been paid to the coordination polymers or supramolecular complexes generated from semirigid organic ligands. Semirigid ligands fill a void between rigid and flexible organic ligands and offer the possibility for construction of frameworks with novel patterns not easily achievable by rigid and flexible ligands. We are interested in how different types of semirigid linking groups as well as different terminal coordinating sites impact the coordination and supramolecular motifs of a variety of metal complexes based on five-membered heteroatom-ring bridging ligands. Following this approach, we have expanded oxadiazole-bridged rigid and flexible ligands to the semirigid ligand L1. The semirigid large-length-scale ligand L1 was synthesized by the reaction of bis(4-bromomethylphenyl)oxadiazole (S) and 1,2,4-triazole in the presence of K2CO3 in CH3CN at ambient temperature in moderate yield. The previous study indicated that the oxadiazole ring is prone to hydrolyze into a carbohydrazide moiety under basic conditions. The results herein demonstrate that the oxadiazole ring is stable under our experimental conditions (K2CO3, r.t.). In addition, L1 is soluble in common polar organic solvents such as CH2Cl2, CHCl3, THF, DMSO, and DMF, which potentially facilitates the solution reactions between L1 and inorganic metal salts. When L1 was treated under hydrothermal conditions (H2O, 190 °C and sealed bomb), L2 was generated as the hydrolysis product in high yield. No carbohydrazide bridging spacer L3 was isolated during the reactions. To further confirm the structure of L2, we analyzed it using single-crystal X-ray diffraction. L2 crystallizes in a chiral space group P2(1). As shown in Figure , phenylcarboxylate and triazole groups are bridged by a methylene group, which gives rise to ligand L2 being unsymmetric with an angular backbone driven by the sp3 configuration of the bridging carbon atom. The dihedral angle between the phenyl ring and the 1,2,4,-triazole ring is 111°. The terminal carboxylate moiety has a 4.5° dihedral angle with the plane of the attached phenyl ring. Such a chiral asymmetric bent organic spacer with divergent properties is potentially useful in the construction of polymeric homochiral helices and especially acentric MOFs with NLO properties. Compared to L1, L2 has relatively poor solubility in common organic solvents at room temperature. Thus, solution reactions based on it are limited.

elements.content: Structural Analysis of Complexes. Complexes 1 − 3. Complexes 1−3 were synthesized by solution reactions. The slow diffusion of an organic solution (THF or CH2Cl2) of L1 into a MeOH solution of MX2 (M = Cu(II), Cd(II); X = NO3 -, Cl-) afforded 1:2 M(II)−L1 adducts with an interesting bimetallic macroring-containing 1D chain motif. It is noteworthy that all these slow diffusion reactions are not affected by the metal-to-ligand mole ratio, solvent intermedia, and counterions.

It is noteworthy that all these slow diffusion reactions are not affected by the metal-to-ligand mole ratio, solvent intermedia, and counterions.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , each Cd(II) center in 1 adopts a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, which is defined by four trans nitrogen donors from four L1 ligands in the equatorial plane, with two monodentate coordination nitrate oxygen groups in the axial positions. The Cd−N distances are 2.302(3) and 2.369(4) Å, respectively, which are comparable to the corresponding Cd−N bond lengths found in related complexes such as {Na4[Cd7(IDC)6]·3bipy·7H2O} n and {(Bu4N)K3Cd7(IDC)6}·6H2O} n . The axial Cd−O distance of 2.397(7) Å is slightly shorter than the corresponding Cd−O bond distance in Cd(NO3)2(1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethyne)1.5, whereas the Cd−O distance is 2.419(7) Å.

elements.content: The Cd(II) octahedra are connected to each other to form an infinite wavelike 1D chain that consists of a 42-membered bimetallic macrocycle-containing building block. In each elliptical ring, the Cd(II)···Cd(II) contact is around 17 Å (Figure ). Figure shows a view perpendicular to three neighbor chains of the polymer. The chains are arranged in sheets extended along the crystallographic ac-plane driven by two sets of interchain π−π interactions13 formed between parallel terminal triazole (d = 3.5 Å) and central oxadiazole (d = 3.7 Å) rings, respectively. The shortest interchain Cd(II)···Cd(II) distance is 8.9 Å. These π−π interaction driven layers are stacked together along the crystallographic [110] direction with a close Cd(II)···Cd(II) interlayer distance of 8.6 Å (Figure S1, Supporting Information). No significant H-bonding interactions have been found in 1.

elements.content: When Cu(NO3)2 was treated with L1 in a CH3CN/CH2Cl2 mixed solvent system, compound 2 was obtained as light blue crystals. X-ray single crystal analysis revealed that complexes 2 and 1 are isostructural (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Cu−N and Cu−O bond lengths are comparable to those of related copper complexes with a similar coordination sphere, for instance, [Cu(2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-oxadiazole)2(H2O)2] (2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-oxadiazole)2(ClO4)2 (CH3OH)(H2O). Again, in 2, 1D chains are held together by interchain π−π interactions of the triazole and oxadiazole rings.

elements.content: Crystal of 3, suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, were obtained from the self-assembly of CuCl2 with ligand L1 in a mixture of CH3CN/H2O at room temperature in 86% yield. The resolved solid-state structure revealed that 3 has a coordination environment around the copper ion similar to that of 2 (Figure S3, Supporting Information). In the solid state, 3 assembles into a 1D wavelike polymer chain, in a manner essentially identical to that of the structurally related complex 2. The major difference between 2 and 3 is that the solid-state arrangement which results from the different counterions. In this case, the two coordination Cl- anions hydrogen bond to the adjacent chains through two sets of symmetric Cl···H−C hydrogen bonds. As shown in Figure , the hydrogen-bonding system involves the Cl(1) and H(8B) atom on the L1 ligands of the neighboring chains. The Cl(1)···H(8B) distance is 2.8 Å, and the corresponding Cl(1)···C(8) distance and Cl(1)···H−C(8) angle are 3.6 Å and 144°, respectively. 1D chains are linked together by such interchain H-bonding systems into a 2D net extended in the crystallographic ac-plane. In addition, two water molecules per formula are fixed by the Cl···H−O hydrogen bond (Cl(1)···H(2W) = 2.316 Å, Cl(1)···O(2) = 3.1 Å and ∠Cl(1)···H(2W)−O(8) = 164°). Again, the packing of 3 is assisted by π−π stacking of the terminal triazole and central oxadiazole rings on L1, which is similar in appearance to that of 2. The hydrogen-bonded 2D nets are linked together through interlayer π−π interactions (Figure S4a, Supporting Information) into a 3D framework that contains parallelogram-like channels extending along the crystallographic [101] direction. The water guest molecules are located in the corners of the channels (Figure S4b, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Compounds 1−3 are air stable. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed that compounds 1 and 2 have a similar thermal decomposition behavior, which is reasonable, since they possess the same polymeric motif. TGA traces indicate that the frameworks of 1 and 2 are stable up to ca. 300 °C. For 3, the hydrogen-bonded water guest molecules were released in the temperature range 80−150 °C, and the framework is stable up to around 300 °C, which is similar to results of 1 and 2. The XRD patterns of as-synthesized 1 and of 1 heated to 300 °C are very consistent with its TGA trace (Figure S5, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Complexes 4 − 6. Compounds 4−6 were synthesized hydrothermally by treating Co(OAc)2, Zn(OAc)2, and CoCl2 with L1 in water at 190 °C, respectively. The carboxylate group in 4−6 evidently results from the hydrolysis of oxadiazole under the reaction conditions. Thus, L2 features the asymmetric organic ligand possessing two different terminal coordination sites in compounds 4−6.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal analysis revealed that compound 4 crystallizes in the chiral and acentric space group P2(1)2(1)2, whose absolute conformation was confirmed on the basis of the Flack's parameter, −0.09(2). As shown in Figure , the Co(II) centers in 4 are four-coordinate. Each Co(II) center coordinates to two monodentate carboxylate groups of two L2 ligands, and to two triazole nitrogen donors of two other L2 ligands. Therefore, the Co(II) atom in 4 adopts a tetrahedral coordination geometry. The Co(1)−O(1) = 1.964(2) Å and Co(1)−N(3) = 2.006(3) Å, which are consistent with those values reported for Co-carboxylate and Co-triazole complexes. The tetrahedral Co(II) centers, however, extend in the crystallographic ac-plane through the bent L2 ligands to form a 2D layered motif instead of a 3D diamondoid structure usually generated from a metal−tetrahedron and linear rigid ligand. As shown in Figure a, the chiral 2D net is composed of Co(II)-L2 single-stranded helical chains running along the crystallographic c-axis with a period of separation of 11.975 Å. All single-stranded left-handed helices are parallel interlaced to each other crossing the cobalt nodes to generate rhombus-like cavities possessing a crystallographic 21 screw axis along the Co(II)···Co(II) direction (Figure b), in which no guest molecules are incorporated. As illustrated in Figure b, the intracage opposite Co(II)···Co(II) diagonal distances across the individual rhombic cavity are ca. 20 and 11 Å, respectively. Interestingly, the 2D Co-L2 net is “double-edged”, which results from the helical Co-L2 subunits (Figure c). The 2D sheets do not interpenetrate, affording a layered structure. As indicated in Figure a, the adjacent sheets are stacked offset with respect to each other along the crystallographic b-axis, which is recognized as an AB−AB arrangement. The nearest interlayer Co−Co distance is 9.6 Å. In the case of 4, the AB−AB stacking of the layers generates reduced, yet still large, infinite parallelogram-like channels of dimensions 8 × 10 Å extended along the crystallographic [111] direction (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: X-ray single-crystal analysis revealed that compound 4 crystallizes in the chiral and acentric space group P2(1)2(1)2, whose absolute conformation was confirmed on the basis of the Flack's parameter, -0.09(2). As shown in Figure , the Co(II) centers in 4 are four-coordinate. Each Co(II) center coordinates to two monodentate carboxylate groups of two L2 ligands, and to two triazole nitrogen donors of two other L2 ligands. Therefore, the Co(II) atom in 4 adopts a tetrahedral coordination geometry. The Co(1)-O(1) = 1.964(2) Å and Co(1)-N(3) = 2.006(3) Å, which are consistent with those values reported for Co-carboxylate and Co-triazole complexes. The tetrahedral Co(II) centers, however, extend in the crystallographic ac-plane through the bent L2 ligands to form a 2D layered motif instead of a 3D diamondoid structure usually generated from a metal-tetrahedron and linear rigid ligand. As shown in Figure a, the chiral 2D net is composed of Co(II)-L2 single-stranded helical chains running along the crystallographic c-axis with a period of separation of 11.975 Å. All single-stranded left-handed helices are parallel interlaced to each other crossing the cobalt nodes to generate rhombus-like cavities possessing a crystallographic 21 screw axis along the Co(II)⋅⋅⋅Co(II) direction (Figure b), in which no guest molecules are incorporated. As illustrated in Figure b, the intracage opposite Co(II)⋅⋅⋅Co(II) diagonal distances across the individual rhombic cavity are ca. 20 and 11 Å, respectively. Interestingly, the 2D Co-L2 net is "double-edged", which results from the helical Co-L2 subunits (Figure c). The 2D sheets do not interpenetrate, affording a layered structure. As indicated in Figure a, the adjacent sheets are stacked offset with respect to each other along the crystallographic b-axis, which is recognized as an AB-AB arrangement. The nearest interlayer Co-Co distance is 9.6 Å. In the case of 4, the AB-AB stacking of the layers generates reduced, yet still large, infinite parallelogram-like  channels of dimensions 8 × 10 Å extended along the crystallographic [111] direction (Figure b).

elements.content: Compound 5 was obtained by the combination of L1 with Zn(OAc)2 under the same reaction conditions as 4. X-ray single-crystal analysis revealed that 4 and 5 are isostructural (Figure S6, Supporting Information). Refinement of the Flack's parameter is 0.005(13), which confirms the enantiomeric purity of the crystal. It is different from 4; the 2D sheet of 5 consists of right-handed helices but with the same pitch as that of 4 (Figure S7, Supporting Information). Again, no guest molecules were found in the rhombus-like cavities.

elements.content: The common feature of compounds 4 and 5 is that they all crystallize in a chiral space group, and both adopt a 2D layered structure that comprises homochiral M-L2 helices. Apparently, such helices arise from the angular geometry16 (the dihedral angle between phenyl and 1, 2, 4-triazole rings is 111°) and asymmetric coordination fashion of L2 and tetrahedral coordination metal nodes. Interestingly, the secondary chiral M-L2 helical chains in 4 and 5 are M- and P-configured, respectively. So far, although many 1D metal−organic helices were reported, the 2D helical polymeric complexes were rarely studied. In general, the combination of the linear rigid symmetric and unsymmetric ligands, such as 4,4‘-bipyridine and pyridinecarboxylates, and the tetrahedral metal nodes will give rise to the 3D diamondoid frameworks; the formation of the 2D double-edged layer structure of 4 and 5 herein obviously resulted from the bent geometry of the semirigid L2. It is noteworthy that the shape and colors of the crystals of 4 or 5 are the same; thus, we could not sort enantiomorphic crystals of 4 or 5 manually. The spontaneous formation of chirality is relatively rare. Compounds 4 and 5 provide additional spontaneous resolution examples of coordination polymers.

elements.content: Combining L1 with CoCl2 in water under hydrothermal conditions (190 °C, 24 h) afforded the compound 6 as red-purple plate crystals in high yield. Single-crystal structure analysis revealed a 3D extended high density framework based on L2 and Co(II) building blocks. Each Co(II) center has a slightly distorted {CoN2O4} octahedral coordination sphere (Figure ), with two nitrogen donors and two oxygen donors of two L2 ligands in the equatorial plane. The coordination sphere is completed by two coordinated water molecules in the axial positions with two relatively long Co−O bond lengths of 2.2747(19) Å. Again, in 6, the carboxylate group is monodentate. A notable feature for the compound 6 is the presence of the zigzag ···Co−O−Co−O··· inorganic chains consisting of Co(II) ions and μ-Oaquo bridging atoms. As shown in Figure , all ···Co−O−Co−O··· chains extend along the crystallographic c-axis. Each identical chain is connected to four neighbor chains through two terminal triazole and monocarboxylate groups alternatively, into the neutral 3D framework.

elements.content: Compounds 4−6 are neutral polymeric complexes, and L2 exists as a deprotonated ligand, which is consistent with the absence of the vibration bands above 1710 cm-1 in their IR spectra. The antisymmetric and symmetric CO stretching frequencies at 1623 and 1366 cm-1 for 4−5 and 1702 and 1422 cm-1 for 6, respectively, tally with the monodentate carboxylate group. Compounds 4 and 5 exhibit similar thermal decomposition behavior due to their identical structural feature. In TGA traces, both 4 and 5 experienced a single-step weight loss that was observed between 350 and 520 °C, which is attributed to the release of the L2 ligands. X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the samples of 4 and 5 after heating to 320 °C are comparable with those of as-synthesized 4 and 5. This indicates that these neutral polymeric complexes are highly stable. For 6, the coordination water molecules could be removed in the range of 90−150 °C. Further weight loss is observed above ca. 180 °C, which means 6 is much less stable than 4 and 5. In addition, complexes 4−6 could be obtained by a combination of the L2 ligand with corresponding metal ions under the same hydrothermal conditions (190 °C, 24 h), but in lower yield, which is confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S8, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Optical Properties. As we know, noncentrosymmetric MOFs have attracted much attention because they are desired candidates for second-order nonlinear materials. Owing to their high thermal stability, neutral noncentrosymmetric compounds 4 and 5 herein could be considered as potential NLO-active materials. For evaluation of their NLO activity, we have performed second harmonic generation (SHG) on powder samples of 4 and 5. The complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in a noncentrosymmetric space group, P21212, which belongs to the crystal class P22ab. According to the principles proposed by Kurtz and Perry, the strength of the SHG efficiency of the complexes was tested by measuring the microcrystalline powder of the complexes. Preliminary experimental results show that 4 and 5 are SHG-active and display powder SHG efficiencies. The relative second harmonic intensity of 4 is 0.5 times versus 5 (Figure ) but versus ca. 0.10 and 0.23 times that of urea, respectively.

elements.content: Luminescent Properties of L1-L2 and Their M(II) Complexes. Inorganic−organic hybrid coordination polymers have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Owing to the higher thermal stability of inorganic−organic coordination polymers and the ability to affect the emission wavelength of organic materials, syntheses of inorganic−organic coordination polymers by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials. In this context, 1,3,4-oxadiazole derivatives due to their good thermal and chemical stabilities and their strong photoluminescence, together with the electron-deficient nature of the oxadiazole ring, have led to their complexes as electron-transporting/hole-blocking materials in hybrid light-emitting materials. We have been exploring the luminescent properties of a series of oxadiazole-containing ligands and organic/inorganic coordination polymers and supramolecular complexes based on them in the solid state. The results indicate that emission colors of the oxadiazole-containing organic spacers were affected by their incorporation into metal-containing coordination compounds. The luminescent properties of L1−L2 and their polymeric compounds 1−6 were investigated in the solid state. Their fluorescence spectra are summarized in Table . As indicated in Figure , in the solid state, L1 exhibits two emission maximum at 392 nm with a shoulder peak at 404 nm (λex = 333 nm), while L2 exhibits one emission maximum at 471 nm (λex = 402 nm). Compounds 1−3 based on L1 show an intense emission maximum at 410 nm with a shoulder at 383 nm for 1 (λex = 355 nm, Figure ), 450 nm with a shoulder band at 425 nm for 2 (λex = 361 nm), and 451 nm with a shoulder at 423 nm for 3 (λex = 364 nm), respectively. Compounds 4−6 based on L2 exhibit one emission maxima at 372 (4, λex = 313 nm, Figure ), 363 (5, λex = 309 nm), and 432 (6, λex = 390 nm), respectively. For 1, the observed emissions are clearly caused by intraligand fluorescent emission because of emission bands similar to L1. Compared to 1, the emission bands for 2 and 3 are clearly red-shifted, which is probably due to different metal centers. In contrast, the blue-shifted emissions of 4−6 have been examined (Table ). As shown above, the L2 in complexes 4−6 is more twisted and resulted in a larger energy gap between π* and π orbitals, which could give rise to the emission wavelength of compounds 4−6 blue-shifted. Thus, the emission colors of the free ligands L1 and L2 are significantly affected by their incorporation into the M(II)-containing polymeric compounds 2−6, as evidenced by the large shift in emission. This implies that these polymeric complexes could be potentially used as luminescent materials.

Two new semirigid ligands 2,5-bis(4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)phenyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L1) and 4-(1H-1,2,4-trizol-1-ylmethyl)benzoic acid (L2) have been prepared. L2 was generated from L1 under hydrothermal conditions (water, 190 °C) in high yield. The coordination chemistry of L1 was investigated by solution and hydrothermal reactions. Compounds 1−3 were produced as metallic macroring-containing 1D chains by the combination of L1 and corresponding metal salts in mixed solvent systems, while the compounds 4−6 were isolated from hydrothermal solutions based on the in situ generated L2 ligand. As mention above, symmetric and unsymmetric semirigid ligands resulted in the construction of polymeric motifs that have not been obtained using rigid and flexible oxadiazole bridging ligands reported by us previously, especially the NLO-active compounds. New MOFs and supramolecular complexes based on the new bent spacers of this type with novel polymeric motifs and properties will be reported quite soon.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two new semirigid ligands 2,5-bis(4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)phenyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L1) and 4-(1H-1,2,4-trizol-1-ylmethyl)benzoic acid (L2) have been prepared. L2 was generated from L1 under hydrothermal conditions (water, 190 °C) in high yield. The coordination chemistry of L1 was investigated by solution and hydrothermal reactions. Compounds 1-3 were produced as metallic macroring-containing 1D chains by the combination of L1 and corresponding metal salts in mixed solvent systems, while the compounds 4-6 were isolated from hydrothermal solutions based on the in situ generated L2 ligand. As mention above, symmetric and unsymmetric semirigid ligands resulted in the construction of polymeric motifs that have not been obtained using rigid and flexible oxadiazole bridging ligands reported by us previously, especially the NLO-active compounds. New MOFs and supramolecular complexes based on the new bent spacers of this type with novel polymeric motifs and properties will be reported quite soon.

Preparation of L1. K2CO3 (0.69 g, 10 mmol) was added with stirring to a solution of bis(4-bromomethylphenyl)oxadiazole (2.04 g, 5 mmol) and 1,2,4-triazole (0.69 g, 10 mmol) in anhydrous CH3CN (50 mL) at ambient temperature under nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was stirred for 12 h at ambient temperature [monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC)]. After removal of solvent under vacuum, the residue was purified on silica gel by column using CH3COCH3 as the eluent to afford L1 as the white crystalline solids (0.79 g, 2.06 mmol). Yield, 41%. mp = 222−224 °C. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3094(s), 2953(w), 1618(w), 1555(m), 1505(s), 1268(s), 1149(s), 1014(s), 821(m), 723(s). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  8.14(s, −NCH−N, 2H), 8.01(s, −CHN−N, 2H), 8.16−7.41(AA‘BB‘, 8H, p-C6H4), 5.45(s, 4H, −CH2−). Anal. Calcd. for C20H16N8O2:  C 62.49, H 4.20, N 29.15; Found:  C 62.89, H 4.30, N 28.75.

Preparation of L2. L1 (40.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) and water (5 mL) were placed in an acid digestion bomb. The mixture was heated at 190 °C for 40 h, cooled to 154 °C at a rate of 6 °C h-1, and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The mixture was held at room temperature for an additional 6 h. Colorless block crystals were isolated from the bomb in 77% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3118(vs), 2950(w), 1693(vs), 1611 m), 1516(s), 1432(m), 1275(s), 1142(s), 1013(m), 870(m), 731(s). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  12.99 (s, 1H, −OH), 8.68 (s, 1H, =C−NCH−N−), 8.00−8.03 (d, 1H, −N−CHN−N−), 7.92−7.32 (AA‘BB‘, 4H, p-C6H4), 5.50 (s, 2H, −CH2−). Anal. Calcd. for C10H9N3O2:  C 59.11, H 4.46, N 20.68; Found:  C 59.89, H 4.10, N 21.26.

Preparation of [Cd(L1) 2 ](NO 3 ) 2 (1). A solution of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (10.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) in methanol (8 mL) was layered onto a solution of L1 (15.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL). The solutions were left for about 3 days at room temperature, and colorless crystals (17.12 mg, 0.034 mmol) were obtained. Yield, 87% (based on L1). IR (KBr, cm-1):  3130(s), 1618(m), 1555(s), 1403(vs), 1322(s), 1128(s), 983(m), 852(s), 726(s). 1HNMR (300 MHz, DMSO, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  8.40 (s, 2H, −C6H4), 8.27−8.25 (d, 2H, −C6H4), 7.95−7.81 (m, 10H, −C6H4), 7.76−7.71 (t, 2H, −C6H4), 7.37 (s, C6H6). Anal. Calcd. for C20H16Cd0.50N9O4 :  C 47.79, H 3.21, N 25.08; Found:  C 47.46, H 3.51, N 24.84.

Preparation of [Cu(L1) 2 ](NO 3 ) 2 (2). A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (2.65 mg, 0.011 mmol) in water (2 mL) was layered onto a solution of L1 (2.5 mg, 0.005 mmol) in CH3CN (2 mL). The solutions were left for 4 days at room temperature, and blue crystals were obtained (2.7 mg, 0.028 mmol). Yield, 84% (based on L1). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3123(s), 1525(m), 1501(m), 1384 (vs), 1127(m), 820 (m), 727(m), 644(m). Anal. Calcd. for C40H32CuN18O8:  C 49.91, H 3.37, N 17.46; Found:  C 49.56, H 3.51, N 17.64. In additional, compound 2 could also be obtained in a water (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O)/methanol (L1) mixed solvent system, which was confirmed by the X-ray single-crystal analysis.

Preparation of [Cu(L1) 2 ]Cl 2 ·2(H 2 O) (3). A solution of CuCl2·2H2O (2.10 mg, 0.012 mmol) in water (2 mL) was layered onto a solution of L1 (2.5 mg, 0.005 mmol) in CH3CN (2 mL). The solutions were left for 4 days at room temperature, and blue crystals were obtained (2.7 mg, 0.029 mmol). Yield, 86% (based on L1). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3136(s), 1583(m), 1517(s), 1500(s), 1128(s), 983(m), 821(m), 723(s), 643(s). Anal. Calcd. for C40H36Cl2CuN16O4:  C 51.15, H 3.86, N 23.86; Found:  C 50.86, H 3.90, N 24.00. In additional, compound 2 could also be obtained in a water (CuCl2)/methanol (L1) mixed solvent system, which was confirmed by the X-ray single-crystal analysis.

Preparation of Co(L2) 2 (4). L1 (40.3 mg, 0.10 mmol), Co(OAc)2·2H2O (94.6 mg, 0.2mmol) and water (5 mL) were placed in an acid digestion bomb (20 mL). The mixture was heated at 190 °C for 40 h, cooled to 154 °C at a rate of 6 °C h-1, and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The mixture was held at room temperature for an additional 6 h. Red-purple block crystals (82 mg, 0.18 mmol) were isolated from the bomb in 84% yield (based on L2). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3114(s), 2991(w), 1623(s), 1568(m), 1365(s), 789(m), 738(m). Anal. Calcd. for C20H16CoN6O4:  C 51.85, H 3.48, N 18.14; Found:  C 51.40, H 3.55, N 18.91. In addition, compound 4 could also be generated directly by combination of L2 and CoCl2·6H2O under the same hydrothermal conditions in lower yield.

Preparation of Zn(L2) 2 (5). L1 (40.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (95.6 mg, 0.2 mmol), and water (5 mL) were placed in an acid digestion bomb (20 mL). The mixture was held at room temperature for an additional 6 h. Red-purple block crystals (85 mg, 0.18 mmol) were isolated from the bomb in 87% yield (based on L2). cln_elements.content:
Compounds 1−3 are air stable. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed that compounds 1 and 2 have a similar thermal decomposition behavior, which is reasonable, since they possess the same polymeric motif. TGA traces indicate that the frameworks of 1 and 2 are stable up to ca. 300 °C. For 3, the hydrogen-bonded water guest molecules were released in the temperature range 80−150 °C, and the framework is stable up to around 300 °C, which is similar to results of 1 and 2. The XRD patterns of as-synthesized 1 and of 1 heated to 300 °C are very consistent with its TGA trace (Figure S5, Supporting Information).

Compounds 4−6 are neutral polymeric complexes, and L2 exists as a deprotonated ligand, which is consistent with the absence of the vibration bands above 1710 cm-1 in their IR spectra. The antisymmetric and symmetric CO stretching frequencies at 1623 and 1366 cm-1 for 4−5 and 1702 and 1422 cm-1 for 6, respectively, tally with the monodentate carboxylate group. Compounds 4 and 5 exhibit similar thermal decomposition behavior due to their identical structural feature. In TGA traces, both 4 and 5 experienced a single-step weight loss that was observed between 350 and 520 °C, which is attributed to the release of the L2 ligands. X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the samples of 4 and 5 after heating to 320 °C are comparable with those of as-synthesized 4 and 5. This indicates that these neutral polymeric complexes are highly stable. For 6, the coordination water molecules could be removed in the range of 90−150 °C. Further weight loss is observed above ca. 180 °C, which means 6 is much less stable than 4 and 5. In addition, complexes 4−6 could be obtained by a combination of the L2 ligand with corresponding metal ions under the same hydrothermal conditions (190 °C, 24 h), but in lower yield, which is confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S8, Supporting Information).

Luminescent Properties of L1-L2 and Their M(II) Complexes. Inorganic−organic hybrid coordination polymers have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Owing to the higher thermal stability of inorganic−organic coordination polymers and the ability to affect the emission wavelength of organic materials, syntheses of inorganic−organic coordination polymers by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials. In this context, 1,3,4-oxadiazole derivatives due to their good thermal and chemical stabilities and their strong photoluminescence, together with the electron-deficient nature of the oxadiazole ring, have led to their complexes as electron-transporting/hole-blocking materials in hybrid light-emitting materials. We have been exploring the luminescent properties of a series of oxadiazole-containing ligands and organic/inorganic coordination polymers and supramolecular complexes based on them in the solid state. The results indicate that emission colors of the oxadiazole-containing organic spacers were affected by their incorporation into metal-containing coordination compounds. The luminescent properties of L1−L2 and their polymeric compounds 1−6 were investigated in the solid state. Their fluorescence spectra are summarized in Table . As indicated in Figure , in the solid state, L1 exhibits two emission maximum at 392 nm with a shoulder peak at 404 nm (λex = 333 nm), while L2 exhibits one emission maximum at 471 nm (λex = 402 nm). Compounds 1−3 based on L1 show an intense emission maximum at 410 nm with a shoulder at 383 nm for 1 (λex = 355 nm, Figure ), 450 nm with a shoulder band at 425 nm for 2 (λex = 361 nm), and 451 nm with a shoulder at 423 nm for 3 (λex = 364 nm), respectively. Compounds 4−6 based on L2 exhibit one emission maxima at 372 (4, λex = 313 nm, Figure ), 363 (5, λex = 309 nm), and 432 (6, λex = 390 nm), respectively. For 1, the observed emissions are clearly caused by intraligand fluorescent emission because of emission bands similar to L1. Compared to 1, the emission bands for 2 and 3 are clearly red-shifted, which is probably due to different metal centers. In contrast, the blue-shifted emissions of 4−6 have been examined (Table ). As shown above, the L2 in complexes 4−6 is more twisted and resulted in a larger energy gap between π* and π orbitals, which could give rise to the emission wavelength of compounds 4−6 blue-shifted. Thus, the emission colors of the free ligands L1 and L2 are significantly affected by their incorporation into the M(II)-containing polymeric compounds 2−6, as evidenced by the large shift in emission. This implies that these polymeric complexes could be potentially used as luminescent materials.
